comments:
I was working on a Swing GUI program using a JPanel visual class and suddenly 
VE stopped rendering my GUI in the top half of the split screen editor. I have 
tried recompiling my program, closing and re-opening the Java class, restarting 
Eclipse, and rebooting my PC but VE still refuses to draw my GUI on the screen. 
I checked the Eclipse workspace log and here is the output:

!ENTRY org.eclipse.ve.java.core 4 0 May 25, 2005 15:19:30.656
!MESSAGE Can not determine equivalency

!ENTRY org.eclipse.ve.java.core 4 0 May 25, 2005 15:19:31.78
!MESSAGE Exception thrown.
!STACK 0
java.lang.ClassCastException: org.eclipse.emf.java.util.JavaResourceImpl
	at 
org.eclipse.ve.internal.java.codegen.core.JavaSourceTranslator.createJavaInstanc
es(JavaSourceTranslator.java:705)
	at 
org.eclipse.ve.internal.java.codegen.core.JavaSourceTranslator.buildCompositionM
odel(JavaSourceTranslator.java:774)
	at 
org.eclipse.ve.internal.java.codegen.core.JavaSourceTranslator.decodeDocument
(JavaSourceTranslator.java:881)
	at 
org.eclipse.ve.internal.java.codegen.core.JavaSourceTranslator.loadModel
(JavaSourceTranslator.java:656)
	at 
org.eclipse.ve.internal.java.codegen.editorpart.JavaVisualEditorPart$Setup.run
(JavaVisualEditorPart.java:1444)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:66)

This is a critical error in my opinion because what use is a visual class 
editor if it does not visualize your Swing application! Any advice or a patch 
would be much appreciated.

Gili, I'm turning this over to you since I'll be out of town for the next
several days... and the stack shows it might be something related to decoding.

Ian, what VE driver are you using? What levels of Eclipse, EMF, and GEF are using?
Also, could you please attach the source code so we can try to recreate your
problem in a debugger (nothing confidential please).

Thanks... Peter Walker
Also, if you are running M1 or higher, try Project->Clean all.

Here is more info about my setup to help resolve this bug. I have tried to use 
Visual Editor in two instances of Eclipse 3.0.2, one with EMF 2.0.1, GEF 3.0.0, 
and VE 1.0.1.1, and another with EMF 2.0.1, GEF 3.0.1, and VE 1.0.1. I even 
tried upgrading from JDK 1.5.0_02 to 1.5.0_03 but still no success.

Attached is a simple Eclipse project I created to test VE's capabilities. 
Please note that I was using VE successfully for many hours to build a more 
complex Swing application before it suddenly stopped working for me. Below is 
the source code of the test program I created using the New > Java > Swing > 
JFrame Visual Class menu option.

Created an attachment (id=21823)
Simple VE test project 

Visual Editor for Eclipse could not to render the Swing GUI in the attached
project.

We have not tested/supporting at this point JDK 1.5.

Can you try to set the project with the Swing app with JRE 1.4.2

(In reply to comment #6)
> We have not tested/supporting at this point JDK 1.5.
> Can you try to set the project with the Swing app with JRE 1.4.2 

I changed my JRE to 1.4.2 but I'm still having problems. Upon opening my visual 
class, VE tries to create a remote VM, compiles my class, and tells me the 
editor and source code are In Sync. Nothing shows up in the visual editor, the 
JavaBeans view is empty, and the Properties view is empty. Here is the stack 
trace:

!ENTRY org.eclipse.ve.java.core 4 0 May 26, 2005 11:12:38.734
!MESSAGE Exception thrown.
!STACK 0
java.lang.ClassCastException: org.eclipse.emf.java.util.JavaResourceImpl
	at

es(JavaSourceTranslator.java:705)
	at

odel(JavaSourceTranslator.java:774)
	at

(JavaSourceTranslator.java:881)

(JavaVisualEditorPart.java:1444)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:66)


If I edit my class, save and recompile, I still get the "Can not determine 
equivalency" exception.

Try one more thing.

Change the IDE's build JRE to be 1.4.2 (Pref->Java->Installed JRE) and check the
1.4.2 one.

Then, project->clean all.

Close/restart the IDE

(In reply to comment #8)
> Try one more thing.
> Change the IDE's build JRE to be 1.4.2 (Pref->Java->Installed JRE) and check 
the
> 1.4.2 one.
> Then, project->clean all.
> Close/restart the IDE

Hi Gili,

I took your advice and the situation is still the same. I created a Java visual 
classes extending JFrame but nothing is displayed in the WYSIWYG editor, the 
JavaBeans view, or the Properties view of the Java perspective. Next I added a 
main method that instantiated the class. Still nothing. Next I removed "extends 
JFrame" from the class definition, created a JFrame instance variable, and 
instantiated it in the initialize() method. This seems to work because I now 
see the GUI in the WYSIWYG editor and I see the JFrame instance as the top node 
in the JavaBeans view. 

I read the Eclipse documentation for VE and I followed the guidelines for 
creating a new visual class, but whenever I choose to extend another Swing 
component the WYSIWYG editor displays nothing and the JavaBeans and Properties 
views are empty. If I create a new visual class without extending a Swing 
component, I can drag and drop a JFrame instance from the palette onto the 
canvas and it displays correctly. Then I can continue to build my GUI using the 
visual tools. This is not what the documentation says to do but it seems to 
work.

I also tried to run some of the Swing visual class examples included with VE. 
None of these displayed correctly in the WYSIWYG editor or JavaBeans and 
Properties views. In fact, the text editor example crashed my computer! This is 
the second time that this has happened to me using VE. VE is a very promising 
Eclipse feature and I would like to continue to use it. If you have any further 
advice I am still interested in resolving this problem. For the moment I will 
have to use the workaround I found by not extending another Swing class in my 
application.

Ian

Anything new to report? What's the status of this bug fix? What am I supposed 
to do????

Try installing VE 1.0.2.  I think this looks like the conflict that occurs with
having the EMF examples plug-in installed with VE < 1.0.2.

Jeff is right, you need to use VE 1.0.2.1. This error occurs due to having EMF
examples installed. We didn't fix the conflict until VE 1.0.2.1

(In reply to comment #12)
> Jeff is right, you need to use VE 1.0.2.1. This error occurs due to having EMF
> examples installed. We didn't fix the conflict until VE 1.0.2.1

I updated to the version you suggested and the problem is solved. Great work 
guys! Thanks to you VE is working again and I'm able to continue building my 
Swing application. This is a fine tool and I'm glad to be able to use it. Many 
thanks.

I'm going to be changing this to worksforme instead of fixed since it wasn't a
defect that we fixed. This is just for tracking purposes so we know what was
actually worked on and fixed by us.
